awd_abstract_narration:
People who have physical disabilities or who have difficulty moving easily often experience discrimination in everyday life.  This project focuses on the dehumanizing treatment of such people.  The research examines how it is that we make judgments about others' worth based on their bodies or on their physical mobility.  It also considers why it is that we sometimes see those lacking physical abilities as also lacking mental abilities.  The long-term goal is to find ways to reduce the dehumanization of people who have mobility challenges.   A new model of dehumanization proposes that we often fail to carefully consider others' minds, especially when those others do not appear able to influence our own lives.  According to this model, people who lack physical mobility (such as the elderly, obese individuals, physically disabled persons) often fail to claim our attention. By failing to think about them, we then fail to consider their minds as being sophisticated and capable. A deeper understanding of this process will support the development of interventions aimed at reducing the discrimination so often experienced by those who have physical disabilities.

Sixteen behavioral experiments examine the link between how others are perceived and the triggering of dehumanizing responses.  It is expected that perceiving others as personally relevant will trigger the perception of more sophisticated minds, and that believing a target is not personally relevant will trigger dehumanizing responses. The first line of work will establish that simple cues to self-relevance (such as an impending interaction or direct eye gaze) will trigger the perception that others' have more sophisticated minds.  The second and third lines of work will extend these findings to physical mobility cues, demonstrating that individuals who have lesser physical mobility will be seen as less capable of acting on the self, and therefore will be ascribed less sophisticated physical capacities.  This project will also extend to interventions to reduce the dehumanization of those with physical disabilities.  It is expected that individuals who are seen as more physically capable (because of effective prostheses) will no longer be dehumanized.  Taken together, this research bridges the interface between person perception, the perception of others' bodies, and mind perception. It also addresses questions about the causes of dehumanizing stigma and how such stigma may be reduced.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research focused on how dehumanizing other people can be the product of how we see their faces and bodies. This work begins to bridge the person perception literature with the literature on dehumanization. 

There are multiple key outcomes of this grant.

One central goal of the grant has been to focus on the dehumanization of individuals whose bodies have limited mobility. Our research has focused both on people with physical disabilities (e.g., Sim & Hugenberg, in press), obese individuals (e.g., Sim, Almaraz, & Hugenberg, 2022a), and imprisoned individuals (Deska, Almaraz, & Hugenberg, 2020).  Across many studies, have seen a number of nuanced findings.

We find that obese individuals are often seen as lacking mental sophistication but not emotional/experiential sophistication. We also find that prisoners -- a group whose mobility is restricted by dint of incarceration -- are also dehumanized (a classic finding), but differently depending on the lenth of sentence remaining (a novel finding). Specifically, as prisoners near their release date, dehumanization of tends to lessen. This appears to be driven by beliefs that prisoners have been rehabilitated their prison sentence. Finally, and unexpected, we found that people with physical disabilities are actually often seen as having very high levels of mental sophsitication relative to non-disabled individauls (Sim & Hugenberg, in press). This was a surprising finding because people with physical disabilities often report dehumanizing treatment in everyday life. However, we found that this effect was explained by the tendency to endorse narratives about physically disabled individuals overcoming adversity. Indeed, common portrayals of people with physical disabilities in popular media often include overcoming the adversities created by physical disabilities to lead otherwise 'normal lives.' We find that when people with physical disabilities are described in ways that do not align with the 'overcoming narratives,' those physically disabled people are dehumanized.

A second central goal of this research was to understand how traditionally groups about which negative stereotypes exist may be dehumanized or stereotyped based on facial and bodily cues. For example, we (Sim, Almaraz, & Hugenberg, 2022b) found that both race and weight create unique patterns of stereotyping. Specifcally, "threat" stereotypes commonly ascribed to Black men (but not other negative stereotypes of Black men) are not applied to obese Black men. We also find that victims of sexual assault are treated differently based on their bodliy cues. Specifically, we (Pagnini et al., in press) find that women with higher waist-to-hip ratio (WHR; or more 'hourglass' figures) are more likely to have their claims of sexual assault believed by third-party observers, relative to women with lower WHR. This suggests the stigma of sexual assault victimization is differentially targeted at women based on their bodliy cues. Finally, we have conducted extensive research on how facial cues are read (and mis-read) across racial lines. For example, we have a number of papers investigating and reviewing how cues about pain (e.g., Deska et al., 2020a, 2020b) and about truth vs. lies (e.g., Lloyd et al., 2021; Lloyd & Hugenberg, 2021) are distored and/or misread by racial stereotypes about traditionally stigmatized groups (e.g., racial minorities).

This NSF grant funded dozens of research studies, resulting in 14 papers published, 2 papers in press, and 2 under review or in preparation, and upported the funding of a laboratory including 7 graduate students' research and travel.
